title: What do staff say about work pressures?
analysis_commentary:
The survey of NHS staff asks employees to score their work pressure: the extent to which the workload is more than they can cope with and the extent they feel there is a lack of time or resources to do their job well. Scores range from 1 to 5; 5 represents staff experience high work pressures.

In 2013, staff reported a score of 3 (i.e. 'neutral response'), which varied little over a decade or between trust types. However, a third of staff (30%) feel that there are enough staff to enable them to do their jobs properly; this is highest amongst mental health/learning disability staff (31%) and lowest amongst ambulance staff (20%) (data not shown).

The results were similar across different staff groups that we reviewed (medical/dental, registered nurses, healthcare assistants, social care, allied health professionals, scientific & technical, general managers, wider healthcare team). One exception was health visitors who tended to report a little less favourably with a score of 3.5 on the 5 point scale (data not shown).

No difference was observed between the sexes of the staff responding, their age, whether the staff has a disability or not, or whether the staff is white or non-white (data not shown).
data_source: Department of Health, Survey of NHS Staff
